title: Photo-synthesis! Fern learns to take selfies by powering a camera's fuel cells
text:
The vibrant colours of nature’s flora have always provided a bucolic background panorama for budding photographers.

But now a plant is making sure it’s in the centre of the frame – by snapping its own selfies.

The fern – nicknamed Pete – has captured the world’s first plant-powered pictures.

The camera’s fuel cells harness the energy of naturally occurring bacteria in the soil, fed by nutrients that plants put into the earth as they grow.

Pete the maidenhair fern is snapping at an ‘astonishing’ rate, say scientists – and currently takes a picture every 20 seconds.

The trial at London Zoo’s Rainforest Life exhibit aims to develop a way of using plants to power cameras and sensors to monitor remote locations.

They could offer an alternative to batteries or solar panels, and help experts understand threats to the natural world such as climate change and habitat loss.

After spending the summer growing, Pete the maidenhair fern is snapping at an ‘astonishing’ rate, say scientists – and currently takes a picture every 20 seconds.

Al Davies, of the Zoological Society of London (ZSL), said: ‘Seeing Pete’s first selfie was an incredible moment. Most power sources have limits but plants can survive in the shade, naturally moving into position to maximise the potential of absorbing sunlight – meaning the potential for plant-powered energy is pretty much limitless.’

The ZSL team will continue to refine the technology before setting up a second trial in the wild.
